title-group.article-title: Pseudepigrapha Notes IV: 5. The Testament of Job. 6. The Testament of Solomon

contrib-group.aff: Department of Religion, Concordia University, 1455 de Maisonneuve Blvd. West, Montréal H3G 1M8, Canada

abstract.p: This is the fourth in a series of articles intended to present the results of manuscript research or provide bibliographic updates relevant to the study of the ‘Old Testament Pseudepigrapha’. It is usually reported that the Testament of Job is extant in three Old Slavonic manuscript copies, and that the Testament of Solomon is preserved in one Syriac manuscript and one Arabic manuscript, both of which remain unpublished. These statements do not accurately reflect our present knowledge.

body.p: This article is the fourth in the series of ‘Pseudepigrapha Notes’.1 It is usually reported that the Testament of Job is extant in three Slavonic manuscript copies, and that the Testament of Solomon is preserved in one Syriac manuscript and one Arabic manuscript, both of which remain unpublished. These statements do not accurately reflect our present knowledge.

sec.title: 1. The Testament of Job
sec.p: The Testament of Job is a haggadic retelling of the biblical story of Job in the form of a farewell address to his children. The earliest evidence for the text is a Sahidic Coptic translation, which is preserved in the fragments of a fourth-century papyrus codex, P. Köln 3221.2 Greek, though, is almost certainly the original language of the Testament, based on its close linguistic relationship and literary similarities with the Septuagint version of the book of Job. Four manuscript copies of the Greek text are known:3

disp-quote.p: P Paris, BnF gr. 2658, fols. 72r–97r (saec. xi).4
P2 Paris, BnF gr. 938, fols. 172v–192v (xvi; transcription of P).
V Città del Vaticano, BAV Vat. gr. 1238, fols. 340v–349v (1195).5

sec.p: The Testament of Job is also preserved in Slavonic. Nearly every study of the Testament records that three manuscript copies are known.7 These are the three used by Jiři Polivka in his 1891 edition, which in the conspectus below are designated PŠ (base text), with variants from MS and NS.8 Yet Berndt Schaller in his 1979 JSHRZ translation and commentary refers to three other manuscripts,9 which Alexsandr Ivanović Jacimirskij in his bibliography had noted over half a century earlier.10 Two additional south Slavonic manuscripts feature in the Serbian translation of a selection of Slavonic apocrypha by Tomislav Jovanović.11

It is now clear that there are no fewer than nine known manuscript copies of the Testament of Job in Slavonic. Two were lost in 1941, although one of these (NS) had been previously edited. Maria Haralambakis is currently preparing a comprehensive study of the Testament, from which this information and the following conspectus is drawn.12 The conspectus identifies and briefly describes the nine manuscript copies, arranged chronologically. Haralambakis has also suggested the use of two-letter abbreviations for the Slavonic manuscripts, to avoid confusion with the established one-letter abbreviations of the Greek manuscripts. The first letter indicates the present location of the manuscript. The second letter indicates the first letter of the name of the codex, the name of the library, or the collection of which it is a part.

tr.td: Beograd, Biblioteka Srpske patrijaršije 219, pp. 267–318 (1381). ‘Tale of the Righteous Job.’ The last few sentences are missing, but a paraphrase of the end of the story is added in a later hand as a marginal note.

Moskva, Rossiyskaya Gosudarstvennaya biblioteka, collection of P.I. Sevastjanov 43, fols. 97v–110v (xv2). ‘Life and Deeds of Job the Righteous.’ Incomplete: contains the Testament of Job until the beginning of ch. 35.
Beograd, Narodna biblioteka Srbiji 506, fols. 24b–47b (xv). Lost in the bombing of Beograd in 1941.

Praha, Knihovna Národní Muzeum IX H 21 (Š12), inheritance of Šafarik, fols. 158r–177v, 188r-v (xviin). ‘May 6, Life and Deeds of the Holy and Righteous Job.’ Fols. 188r-v contain parts of chs. 43–46. A rebinding error has caused the text to extend from fol. 174v to fol. 188r-v, and then back to fol. 175r.
Beograd, Muzej Srpske Pravoslavne Crkve, collection of Radoslav Grujić 219, fols. 53v–68r (xvimed). ‘Life and Deeds of Job the Righteous, Father Bless.’

Sankt Petersburg, Academy of Sciences, collection of Sirku, 13.4.10, fols. 122r–151v. (xvi). ‘Month of May the Sixth Day, the Commemoration of the Righteous Job, Father Bless.’ The text is preserved to the end, but incomplete, with the following omissions: the end of ch. 4–15, 16–20, as well as two omissions of a few lines each in chs. 37–38 and 41–42.

Beograd, Narodna biblioteka Srbiji 487 (149), fols. 51v–71v (xvii). ‘Story and Tale of Job who was formerly called Jobab the Rich.’ This manuscript was also lost in the bombing of 1941, but its copy of the Testament had been edited by S. Novaković in 1878.13 Incomplete: missing sections 3.6 to ch. 19, 32–34.4, and 41.4 to ch. 43. Novaković bridged these gaps by inserting Serbo-Croatian translations of J.-P. Migne's French translation of A. Mai's edition of the Greek manuscript V.14 Overall, the NS manuscript has a tendency to shorten the wording of the text, which affects especially the poems and other ‘repetitious’ passages.

Sofia, Archiv na Bûlgarska akademia na naukite (ABAN) 86, known as the ‘Popstojkov Damaskin’, fols. 47v–51v + (the portion of the manuscript containing the Testament saec. xvii2). ‘Tale of the Rich Job, How He Suffered from the Envy of the Devil.’ Fragment containing the Testament of Job 1–22, but very incomplete. Between fols. 51 and 52 there are approximately forty unnumbered, fragmentary leaves, whose text is difficult to identify. The Testament continues for at least two more leaves after fol. 51v. Altogether the leaves are in a poor state of preservation, and often only a strip of paper close to the binding remains.

sec.p: As a last note on the subject, manuscript 747 (276) of the Narodna Biblioteka Sv. Sv. Kiril i Metodij, Sofia (saec. xviiiex), contains a composition with the intriguing title ‘Commemoration of the Holy and Righteous Job Who Suffered Much’. This is not the Testament of Job, however, but a version of the prose framework of the biblical book of Job in Slavonic.15

sec.title: 2. The Testament of Solomon
sec.p: The Testament of Solomon, rich in esoteric lore, recounts how, with the aid of a magic ring, Solomon conscripted demons in order to build the Temple in Jerusalem.16 The basic narrative appears to have survived in at least 16 Greek manuscript copies, but there is little consensus on the relationship among the recensions, which exhibit great differences, or regarding which recension preserves the earliest form of the text.17

sec.p: The oldest copy of the Testament is represented by the fragments of the Vienna papyrus, which date from the fifth or sixth century and contain portions of ch. 18, according to the common numeration of the text.19

It is often reported that the Testament of Solomon also exists in one Syriac manuscript (Paris, BnF syr. 194, fols. 153r–156v) and one Arabic manuscript (Città del Vaticano, BAV Vat. ar. 448, fols 39r–54r), both of which remain unpublished.20 However, the Parisian text is not Syriac but Karshuni, that is, Arabic written in Syriac script. This fact was recognized by James Charlesworth but has been overlooked by some of the later authorities.21 Slavomír Čéplö has since examined this text. He concludes that despite its title, it is not a copy of the Testament of Solomon, but a late Christian-Arabic composition belonging to the genre of testaments written by kings and rulers for their successors.22

As for the Vatican manuscript, Juan Pedro Monferrer-Sala published a critical edition of its text in 2006.23 According to him, it is not a copy of the Testament of Solomon as it is known from the Greek recensions, but a Christian-Arabic work titled the Aḥkâm Sulaymân, or the ‘Testamento [<veredictos] de Salomón’. It is preserved in fols. 29r [not 39r]-54r (saec. xvii) of the manuscript, and contains portions of the Testament in a rather different form than the Greek text. In his edition, Monferrer-Sala collates the Vatican text with that of a second copy (Paris, BnF ar. 214, fols. 186r–203r [1538]), which Gérard Troupeau in his 1972 catalogue labels Les jugements de Salomon.24

The Aḥkâm Sulaymân is also the subject of Čéplö's aforementioned paper. Čéplö, who wrote without knowing of the existence of Monferrer-Sala's edition,25 likewise concludes that the Judgments of Solomon, as he calls the text, is not a translation of any known recension of the Testament of Solomon, even though it draws heavily from its material. Importantly, he identifies three new manuscripts which after an examination by autopsy might prove to preserve a copy of the Judgments. These are Cairo, Dayr Mār Mīnā 120, fols. 34r–53v, Cairo, Coptic Museum 67, and Cairo, Coptic Museum 31 (xvii), the latter having already been cited by Georg Graf in the first volume of his History.26

Graf identifies other manuscripts which might contain copies of the Testament of Solomon, including Strasbourg or. 4180 (ar. 33), fols. 188r–192r (xvi), and Cairo 645 (1719), fol. 166v ff.27 There are references in Troupeau's catalogue to a ‘Testament de Salomon, fils de David’ in Paris, BnF ar. 28, fols. 137–139 (1539), and in Ugo Zanetti's inventory of the manuscripts of Dair Abû Maqâr to a text concerning ‘l'anneau de Salomon, cf. Testament de Salomon’ in MS no. 411.28

To these catalogue references may be added the manuscript copies of Solomonic texts that preserve a small portion (or a version of a portion) of the Testament of Solomon. One example is the Coptic Legend of Solomon and Thabor, which is the title Scott Carroll gives to a fragmentary writing preserved in a tenth-century Coptic manuscript in the John Rylands University Library, Manchester (JRylLib 85).29 According to Čéplö, Story V of the Aḥkâm Sulaymân is a direct translation of this Coptic text.30 Another example is the so-called Hygromanteia of Solomon, an intriguing composition studied most recently by Pablo Torijano, who notes the existence of 14 manuscript copies.31 Two copies are extant in codices which also contain a copy of the Testament (Harley 5596 [siglum T] and Ambrosianus 1030 [U]).32 Two other copies (Petropolitanus 3 and Petropolitanus 4) are extant in codices which also contain a fragment of the portion of the Testament that lists the 36 decans of ch. 18.33

It is not too much to say that despite the good work of the past, more research on the manuscript traditions of the Testament of Solomon and closely related Solomonic texts remains to be done.34 It might also be the case that at one point we will be compelled to reconsider what we mean by the ‘Testament of Solomon’.

In 1970 Mario Naldini published a paper describing a papyrus fragment, located in the Istituto Papirologico ‘G. Vitelli’ (inv. 319) in Firenze. The fragment preserves a small portion of an exorcism text in Greek, which according to Naldini contains ‘un significativo riferimento al Testamento di Salomone, e di analogie non meno sorprendenti con espressioni contenute nell’ Ordo Baptismi di alcuni rituali della Liturgia latina'. See ‘Un frammento esorcistico e il Testamento di Salomone’, Studia Florentina. Alexandro Roncini sexagenario oblata (Roma: Edizione dell' Ateneo, 1970), pp. 281–87. McCown, The Testament of Solomon, pp. 27–28 n.3, discusses the possibility of Latin and Georgian copies of the Testament.

Carroll's paper provides a fine overview of the history of the tradition of Solomon's association with demons, while the volumes of Torijano, Klutz, and Busch provide a solid footing for the next stage of research.
